en_results_raw: When I was in junior high, I set a school record for the highest number of consecutive detention days—what happens when you refuse to do anything the teachers ask you to do, from homework to classwork. I would sit in the corner of the classroom, staring blankly at the chalkboard, while the teacher tried to engage me in conversation. The only thing I could think about was how I could avoid the lesson. I remember one day, I even managed to get a detention by refusing to stand up when the principal called my name. The teachers tried everything, from offering me extra recess to promising me a reward, but nothing worked. It wasn't until I was in high school that I realized that my behavior was not just a phase but a sign of deeper issues. I had always been a perfectionist, and the pressure to perform well in school was overwhelming. I was afraid of making mistakes, and the fear of failure was paralyzing. It took me years to understand that it's okay to make mistakes and that learning is a process. Now, looking back, I can see that my early struggles were a form of rebellion against a system that didn't seem to understand me. I wish I had found a way to communicate my feelings back then, but I was too lost in my own world to see a way out.

It wasn’t about coffee or friends; it was about priorities. And that, I decided, was something worth holding onto.

en_second_half: glass would surely be preferable. Then, at some point along the way, I began thinking in terms of functions, variables, conditional loops. en_results_raw: With each new language, I realized that the challenges were not just about syntax but about understanding the underlying principles that made each language unique. I spent countless hours debugging, reading documentation, and experimenting with code snippets. The journey from C++ to Python was particularly enlightening, as I discovered the power of readability and simplicity in Python. It was a stark contrast to C++, where every line of code felt like a battle. SQL came next, and it was a revelation to see how data could be manipulated and queried so efficiently. HAL/S, a language used in early space missions, was a fascinating dive into the past, teaching me about the constraints and requirements of real-time systems. Each language added a new layer to my programming toolkit, and I found myself constantly evolving, always learning, and always curious about what the next language would bring. The skills I acquired were not just technical; they were a mindset, a way of approaching problems that transcended the code itself. This journey has been more than just about mastering languages; it's been about understanding the world through the lens of computation and logic.

en_first_half: As we all know, in early 2010, the rover Spirit became stuck in a sand trap, was unable to reorient its solar panels toward the sun, and froze to death as a consequence of its lack of power. Something very similar happened eight years later to Opportunity, which went into hibernation when a maelstrom blocked sunlight and prevented it from recharging its
en_second_half: batteries. Obviously, the risk of losing control of rovers because of extreme weather events is high. To address this, Dr. Arroyo has designed a promising internal system that is less likely to fail in the case of unpredictable meteorological situations. She proposes to build a model and test its efficacy on the next expedition at the Arctic Mars Analog in Svalbard (AMASE)—
en_results: As the dust storm lingered for weeks, Opportunity's batteries drained to critical levels, and the rover entered a deep hibernation mode, conserving what little power remained. NASA engineers, in a race against time, attempted to communicate with Opportunity, sending commands to tilt its solar panels toward the sun as the storm finally began to dissipate. Despite their efforts,
en_results_raw: As the dust storm lingered for weeks, Opportunity's batteries drained to critical levels, and the rover entered a deep hibernation mode, conserving what little power remained. NASA engineers, in a race against time, attempted to communicate with Opportunity, sending commands to tilt its solar panels toward the sun as the storm finally began to dissipate. Despite their efforts, Opportunity did not respond, and on February 13, 2019, NASA officially declared the rover lost. The mission, which had spanned 14 years, had been a remarkable success, providing invaluable data about the Martian surface and atmosphere. The loss of Opportunity was a significant blow to the Mars Exploration Program, but it also served as a reminder of the challenges of space exploration. The Spirit and Opportunity rovers, along with other missions like Curiosity and Perseverance, have collectively transformed our understanding of Mars, revealing a planet with a complex geological history and the potential for past life. As scientists continue to analyze the data collected by these missions, the legacy of Spirit and Opportunity will undoubtedly shape future exploration efforts.

en_second_half: big splashy news. Initially I wasn’t a fan, but I must admit that as a supervisor he’s been nothing but supportive. He’s the one who selected me for the expedition to begin with, and he encouraged me to apply for funding once I went to him with my project idea.
en_results: Dr. Merel stand out. He's the kind of person who believes that only groundbreaking discoveries should be shared, and anything less is a waste of time. This attitude can be both inspiring and intimidating. I remember one particular project where we were working on
en_results_raw: Dr. Merel stand out. He's the kind of person who believes that only groundbreaking discoveries should be shared, and anything less is a waste of time. This attitude can be both inspiring and intimidating. I remember one particular project where we were working on a new technique for collecting Martian soil samples. Dr. Merel was relentless in his pursuit of perfection, pushing us to refine our methods over and over again. It was exhausting, but in the end, our results were nothing short of spectacular. He has this uncanny ability to see potential in the most mundane tasks and turn them into high-impact research. Despite his rigid demeanor, he's also incredibly supportive of his team, always encouraging us to push the boundaries of what's possible. His obsession with results has driven many of us to achieve things we never thought we could. While I may not always agree with his methods, there's no denying that Dr. Merel has left an indelible mark on the AMASE mission and the broader NASA community. His influence extends far beyond the lab, shaping the way we approach scientific exploration and discovery.
